title: Suite Administration for shared service providers
content:
Shared service providers can use Suite Administration to set up a multi-tenant (MT) environment to manage their business units' and clients' request and incident records in one user interface via an MT console. Each business unit and client can use its own tenant while the MT console displays all data together in one consolidated view.

Set up MT environment

To set up the MT environment, complete the following tasks as a suite admin user or a shared service admin user:

Prepare provider tenants

Prepare a provider tenant with these steps:

  1. Create an account of Shared service type being Provider. This account hosts the shared service admin users and agents.
  2. Add users to the provider account. Four roles are available for users, among which:
    • Shared service admin users are assigned with MT Administrator role in Service Management automatically.
    • Shared service agents are assigned with MT Agent role in Service Management automatically.
  3. Create a provider tenant under the created provider account, and then assign a license and deploy the tenant.

Prepare managed tenants

Prepare a managed tenant with these steps:

  1. Create an account of Shared service type being Managed.
  2. Add users to the managed account.
  3. Create a managed tenant under the created managed account, and then assign a license and deploy the tenant.

Add managed tenants to provider tenants

After the provider tenant and managed tenant are created and deployed, go back to the provider tenant, click Shared service tab, and add managed tenant and shared service users to the provider tenant.

Note Updates of the managed tenants and shared service users in Suite Administration are synchronized to Service Management in one direction.

  • In the Managed tenant panel, click Add to add a managed tenant.

    To remove a selected managed tenant, click the right arrow on the tenant and then click Remove.
     
  • In the User access panel, click Add to add users with shared service admin and shared service agent roles to access the data of the selected managed tenant.

    Note If the shared service admin and shared service agent need to access Suite Administration, the suite admin must first create an Access Control List (ACL) to grant data access to a shared service user before the shared service agent can be assigned to a managed tenant. For more information, see Access control.

    Two types of data are accessible for users: Incident and Request. The users having access to Incident data are assigned with Incident Manager role in Service Management automatically. The users having access to Request data are assigned with Service Request Manager role in Service Management automatically.

    To edit the permission granted to a user, click the down arrow on the user and then click Grant permission.

    To remove a selected user, click the down arrow on the user and then click Remove.

Now the MT environment configuration is done and the MT Console is ready for use. For detailed instructions on how to use MT Console, see MT console for shared providers.

Roles and permissions for provider and managed tenants

Any shared service users accessing records in managed tenants are added as users with appropriate roles in the managed tenants automatically.

Service Management tenant  Roles in Service Management Applied to
Provider tenant MT Administrator Admin only. Users with this role can add MT agent to the managed tenants.
MT Agent All users who access managed tenant records.
Managed tenant Service Request Manager (recommended)

All users who access request data of this managed tenant.

If this role isn't assigned, then applicable view and/or edit permissions on requests and all related record types (such as person, group, service) must be assigned to these users.
Incident Manager (recommended)

All users who access incident data of this managed tenant.

If this role isn't assigned, then applicable view and/or edit permissions on incidents and all related record types (such as person, group, service) must be assigned to these users.

Limitations

In multi-tenant (MT) environments, when you have two tabs for two different tenants open in the same browser and log in with the same shared service user, if you operate a request for tenant A and then go to the other tab for tenant B, when you:

  • Open a link of tenant B in a new window
  • Open a link of tenant B from the bookmark
  • Open a link of tenant B from the UI components other than the grid, for example, from the preview card when you hover over a field
  • Open a link that goes to an external system, for example, to HCMX 

The tenant ID in the URL changes to the ID of tenant A and the Page not found error occurs. In such cases, you need to manually change the ID back to the tenant ID of tenant B in the URL.
